From Classical to Quantum and Back: Hamiltonian Adaptive Resolution Path Integral, Ring Polymer, and Centroid Molecular Dynamics

Karsten Kreis Max-Planck-Institut für Polymerforschung, Ackermannweg 10, 55128 Mainz, Germany Graduate School Material Science in Mainz, Staudingerweg 9, 55128 Mainz, Germany    Kurt Kremer Max-Planck-Institut für Polymerforschung, Ackermannweg 10, 55128 Mainz, Germany    Raffaello Potestio potestio@mpip-mainz.mpg.de Max-Planck-Institut für Polymerforschung, Ackermannweg 10, 55128 Mainz, Germany    Mark E. Tuckerman mark.tuckerman@nyu.edu Department of Chemistry, New York University (NYU), New York, NY 10003, USA Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, NYU, New York, NY 10012, USA NYU-East China Normal University Center for Computational Chemistry at NYU Shanghai, Shanghai 200062, China
(March 14, 2024)
Abstract

Path integral-based simulation methodologies play a crucial role for the investigation of nuclear quantum effects by means of computer simulations. However, these techniques are significantly more demanding than corresponding classical simulations. To reduce this numerical effort, we recently proposed a method, based on a rigorous Hamiltonian formulation, which restricts the quantum modeling to a small but relevant spatial region within a larger reservoir where particles are treated classically. In this work, we extend this idea and show how it can be implemented along with state-of-the-art path integral simulation techniques, such as ring polymer and centroid molecular dynamics, which allow the approximate calculation of both quantum statistical and quantum dynamical properties. To this end, we derive a new integration algorithm which also makes use of multiple time-stepping. The scheme is validated via adaptive classical–path-integral simulations of liquid water. Potential applications of the proposed multiresolution method are diverse and include efficient quantum simulations of interfaces as well as complex biomolecular systems such as membranes and proteins.

I Introduction

Quantum delocalization of light atomic nuclei plays an important role in many soft matter systems, ranging from low temperature helium or hydrogen Scharf, Martyna, and Klein (1993); Ceperley (1995); Azuah et al. (1997); Nozières and Pines (1999); Lindenau et al. (2006) to complex biological systems at room temperature. Examples include proton transfer in biomolecules and membranes Löwdin (1963); Rein and Harris (1964); Haines (2001); Jeuken, Bushby, and Evans (2007); Pérez et al. (2010); Smirnov, Mourokh, and Nori (2011); Jacquemin et al. (2014), thermodynamics of ice Pamuk et al. (2012), water adlayers on catalysts Li et al. (2010); Nagata et al. (2012), aqueous proton and hydroxide transport Marx et al. (1999); Schmitt and Voth (1999); Tuckerman, Marx, and Parrinello (2002); Wu et al. (2008); Berkelbach, Lee, and Tuckerman (2009); Marx, Chandra, and Tuckerman (2010), and even the structure and dynamics of bulk water Morrone and Car (2008); Paesani et al. (2010); Ceriotti et al. (2013); Fritsch et al. (2014); Ceriotti et al. (2016).

In computer simulations, nuclear quantum effects are typically modeled using Feynman’s path integral (PI) formulation of quantum statistical mechanics Feynman and Hibbs (1965); Ceperley (1995); Tuckerman (2010). The atomic nuclei are mapped onto classical ring polymers, whose beads correspond to the imaginary time slices of the PI. Based on this approach, various techniques have been developed to compute approximate quantum mechanical properties. Path integral molecular dynamics (PIMD) Chandler and Wolynes (1981); Parrinello and Rahman (1984); Hall and Berne (1984); Berne and Thirumalai (1986); Tuckerman et al. (1993); Martyna, Hughes, and Tuckerman (1999); Tuckerman (2010) and path integral Monte Carlo (PIMC) Pollock and Ceperley (1984); Tuckerman et al. (1993); Tuckerman (2010) directly sample the Hamiltonian obtained after path integral quantization and can be employed to calculate time-independent quantum statistical properties. Centroid molecular dynamics (CMD) Cao and Voth (1994a, b, c, d, e, 1996); Martyna (1996); Cao and Martyna (1996); Jang and Voth (1999); Hone, Rossky, and Voth (2006); Pérez, Tuckerman, and Müser (2009); Polyakov, Lyubartsev, and Vorontsov-Velyaminov (2010), which follows the artificial dynamics of the ring-polymer centroids, and ring polymer molecular dynamics (RPMD) Craig and Manolopoulos (2004); Braams and Manolopoulos (2006); Hone, Rossky, and Voth (2006); Pérez, Tuckerman, and Müser (2009); Habershon et al. (2013); Rossi, Ceriotti, and Manolopoulos (2014), which is based on the evolution of the individual PI beads, additionally enable the calculation of approximate quantum dynamical properties.

However, PI-based methods are significantly more expensive than corresponding classical simulations. To overcome this, different techniques have been proposed. For example, ring polymer contraction (RPC) Markland and Manolopoulos (2008a, b); Marsalek and Markland (2016); John et al. (2016) makes use of the fact that long-ranged and non-bonded interactions typically do not need to be evaluated on as many PI beads as bonded interactions. A related technique is the mixed time slicing scheme Steele et al. (2011), in which different particles are described with a different number of imaginary time slices. Other approaches include higher-order Trotter factorization Takahashi and Imada (1984); Jang, Jang, and Voth (2001); Suzuki, Tachikawa, and Shiga (2010); Pérez and Tuckerman (2011); Poltavsky and Tkatchenko (2016) and advanced thermostating procedures based on generalized Langevin equations (GLE) Ceriotti, Bussi, and Parrinello (2009); Ceriotti et al. (2010); Ceriotti, Manolopoulos, and Parrinello (2011); Ceriotti and Manolopoulos (2012). Additionally, multiple time-stepping (MTS) techniques are frequently employed in PI simulations to decouple the computation of the expensive but slowly varying non-bonded forces and the high frequency internal motion of the ring polymers Tuckerman, Berne, and Martyna (1992); Tuckerman et al. (1993); Martyna, Hughes, and Tuckerman (1999).

Most of these methods correspond to a modification of the path integral computation itself. A different approach is provided by adaptive resolution methods, which restrict the PI description to a small subregion within the simulation box and couple it with a classical model. The available computational resources can then be concentrated on the quantum (QM) subregion leading to an overall speedup compared with full QM simulations. This strategy is useful when only a small part of the overall large system actually needs to be described taking into account quantum delocalization effects, which might be the case, for example, in simulations of surfaces, membranes or the active site of a protein. One such method, based on the adaptive resolution simulation scheme (AdResS) Praprotnik, Delle Site, and Kremer (2005, 2008); Fritsch et al. (2012), is the direct spatial interpolation of a classical force field with the PI-based forces obtained after quantization Poma and Delle Site (2010, 2011); Potestio and Delle Site (2012); Agarwal and Delle Site (2015, 2016). This method is, however, not compatible with an overall Hamiltonian description and, thus, inconsistent with the PI formalism Delle Site (2007). Nevertheless, it can, in principle, be used to simulate open quantum systems Wang et al. (2013); Agarwal et al. (2015), for example.

Recently, we proposed a related multiresolution quantum–classical method that, instead of interpolating forces, directly changes the “quantumness”, quantum character, or degree of quantum delocalization of the particles themselves Kreis et al. (2016a). In the QM region, the ring polymers are defined as usual, while in the classical region they collapse to point-like particles, thereby effectively behaving classically. When diffusing between the different regions, the particles change their resolution on the fly. Furthermore, the number of particles in the QM region is not fixed but is allowed to fluctuate. Hence, the scheme can, for example, be used to simulate a quantum grand canonical ensemble efficiently. The approach is derived in a rigorous fashion from the bottom up and is also compatible with a Hamiltonian description. When restricting the QM part to a small but relevant region in space, the scheme leads to a significant computational speedup. In the example of our previous paper, a liquid parahydrogen system, the calculation of the particle pair interactions was accelerated by a factor of ≈10absent10\approx 10. Furthermore, the approach can be combined with the previously mentioned methods for efficient PI simulations, such as RPC or GLE thermostating. Therefore, approaching the problem from a different perspective and reducing the number of PI-based interactions in the system, our method is complementary to techniques that make the PI computations themselves more efficient.

In our previous paper Kreis et al. (2016a), we proposed the general Hamiltonian adaptive quantum–classical scheme, performed a simple validation of the method using a Monte Carlo algorithm to sample the hybrid Hamiltonian, and demonstrated that the approach can speed up PI-based simulations. In this follow-up article, we show how the method can be extended to perform Hamiltonian multiresolution quantum–classical CMD and RPMD simulations. To this end, we derive an MTS integration protocol suited for the proposed methodology and validate the method by adaptive quantum–classical simulations of liquid water.

Our scheme enables efficient simulations of complex systems by locally taking into account QM delocalization effects. This can be useful, for example, for interface systems and in simulations of biological objects such as membranes or proteins. Additionally, as previously noted, it allows an efficient implementation of the QM grand canonical ensemble and can, in principle, also be combined with quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics (QM/MM) approaches, in particular those which are based on a similar Hamiltonian interpolation scheme Boereboom et al. (2016).

The paper is organized as follows: In section II, we review the adaptive quantum–classical scheme proposed in our previous work, and in section III we present its implementation within the PIMD framework. In section IV, we discuss how to use the methodology to calculate approximate quantum dynamical quantities in the context of adaptive RPMD and CMD simulations. We describe the details of the simulations we performed for validation in section V and the results are discussed in section VI. In section VII, we summarize the article and conclude.

II Quantum–classical path integrals

In quantum statistical mechanics, the partition function of a system of N𝑁N interacting particles with indices α𝛼\alpha, momenta 𝐩^αsubscript^𝐩𝛼\hat{\mathbf{p}}_{\alpha}, masses mαsubscript𝑚𝛼m_{\alpha}, kinetic energy 𝒦^=∑α=1N𝐩^α2/2​mα^𝒦superscriptsubscript𝛼1𝑁superscriptsubscript^𝐩𝛼22subscript𝑚𝛼\hat{\mathcal{K}}=\sum_{\alpha=1}^{N}\hat{\mathbf{p}}_{\alpha}^{2}/2m_{\alpha} and potential energy 𝒱^^𝒱\hat{\mathcal{V}} is Q=Tr[exp(−βℋ)^]Q=\textmd{Tr}[\exp{(-\beta\hat{\mathcal{H})}}] with the inverse temperature β=1/kb​T𝛽1subscript𝑘𝑏𝑇\beta=1/k_{b}T and the Hamiltonian ℋ^=𝒦^+𝒱^^ℋ^𝒦^𝒱\hat{\mathcal{H}}=\hat{\mathcal{K}}+\hat{\mathcal{V}}. When performing PI quantization using P𝑃P imaginary time slices (Trotter number P𝑃P), the kinetic energy term gives rise to a configurational energy that is equivalent to the one of a classical ring polymer with P𝑃P beads, which are coupled via harmonic springs (for a detailed derivation see, for example, Tuckerman Tuckerman (2010)). This mapping from a quantum particle onto a classical polymer ring is exact in the limit P→∞→𝑃P\rightarrow\infty. In practice, however, well converged results can be obtained for finite values of P𝑃P, which typically range from 16 to 48 beads for standard PI simulations aimed at treating nuclear quantum effects under ambient conditionsPérez et al. (2010); Tuckerman and Marx (2001); Habershon, Markland, and Manolopoulos (2009); Fritsch et al. (2014); Wang, Ceriotti, and Markland (2014); Wilkins, Manolopoulos, and Dang (2015); Miller III and Manolopoulos (2005).

The strength of the spring constants between the beads of the ring polymers is m​ωP2𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝜔2𝑃m\omega^{2}_{P} with ωP=P/β​ℏsubscript𝜔𝑃𝑃𝛽Planck-constant-over-2-pi\omega_{P}=\sqrt{P}/\beta\hbar. It is proportional to the temperature as well as the particles’ masses. In other words, the ring polymers are more collapsed the higher the temperature and the heavier the particles. The extension of the ring polymers can be interpreted as a measure of the “quantumness” or quantum character of the QM particles, with classical behavior corresponding to fully collapsed and therefore localized ring polymers.

The previously proposed method for quantum–classical adaptive resolution simulations Kreis et al. (2016a) is based on the following observation: In a PI-based formulation of quantum statistical mechanics the only role of a particle’s mass is to determine the spring constant. It determines the extent to which a particle exhibits its quantum character. The scheme is as follows: For each particle α𝛼\alpha we define a resolution parameter λα=λ​(𝐫^α)subscript𝜆𝛼𝜆subscript^𝐫𝛼\lambda_{\alpha}=\lambda(\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{\alpha}) that is a function of the particle’s position 𝐫^αsubscript^𝐫𝛼\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{\alpha}. It smoothly changes from 111 in a spatially predefined QM region to 00 in a classical (CL) region via an intermediate hybrid (HY) transition region (see Fig. 1).

Based on this resolution function, we then define a variable mass of particle α𝛼\alpha as mα→μα​(λα)=λα​mα+(1−λα)​Mα→subscript𝑚𝛼subscript𝜇𝛼subscript𝜆𝛼subscript𝜆𝛼subscript𝑚𝛼1subscript𝜆𝛼subscript𝑀𝛼m_{\alpha}\rightarrow\mu_{\alpha}(\lambda_{\alpha})=\lambda_{\alpha}m_{\alpha}+(1-\lambda_{\alpha})M_{\alpha}. Therefore, in the QM region μα​(1)=mαsubscript𝜇𝛼1subscript𝑚𝛼\mu_{\alpha}(1)=m_{\alpha} where mαsubscript𝑚𝛼m_{\alpha} is the real mass of the particles while in the CL region μα​(0)=Mα≫mαsubscript𝜇𝛼0subscript𝑀𝛼much-greater-thansubscript𝑚𝛼\mu_{\alpha}(0)=M_{\alpha}\gg m_{\alpha}. The mass Mαsubscript𝑀𝛼M_{\alpha} must be chosen large enough that the particles with μα​(0)=Mαsubscript𝜇𝛼0subscript𝑀𝛼\mu_{\alpha}(0)=M_{\alpha} behave essentially classically (in our previous work, we used Mα=100​mαsubscript𝑀𝛼100subscript𝑚𝛼M_{\alpha}=100\,m_{\alpha}). In this way, particles in the QM region exhibit proper QM behavior, while in the CL region the ring polymers are forced to collapse to nearly point-like particles and behave classically. Note, also, that the mass Mαsubscript𝑀𝛼M_{\alpha} is not employed, in the MC framework just discussed, to evolve a time-dependent dynamics of the system, which on the other hand is the object of the present study.

In addition to variable masses, we also use the Hamiltonian adaptive resolution simulation (H-AdResS) formalism Potestio et al. (2013a, b); Kreis et al. (2014); Español et al. (2015), which can be employed to couple different force fields via interpolation of potential energies. A classical H-AdResS Hamiltonian H𝐻H of a system of N𝑁N interacting molecules reads

H=𝒦+∑α=1N[λα​Vα1+(1−λα)​Vα0+Vαint−Δ​H​(Rα)]𝐻𝒦superscriptsubscript𝛼1𝑁delimited-[]subscript𝜆𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑉1𝛼1subscript𝜆𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑉0𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑉int𝛼Δ𝐻subscriptR𝛼\displaystyle H=\mathcal{K}+\sum_{\alpha=1}^{N}\left[{\lambda_{\alpha}}{V^{1}_{\alpha}}+{(1-\lambda_{\alpha})}{V^{0}_{\alpha}}+V^{\textrm{int}}_{\alpha}-\Delta H(\textbf{R}_{\alpha})\right] (1)

where 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} is the kinetic energy, α𝛼\alpha indexes the N𝑁N particles, and λα=λ​(Rα)subscript𝜆𝛼𝜆subscriptR𝛼\lambda_{\alpha}=\lambda(\textbf{R}_{\alpha}) is the previously defined resolution function (when assigning single resolution values λαsubscript𝜆𝛼\lambda_{\alpha} to whole molecules one typically uses the molecular center of mass RαsubscriptR𝛼\textbf{R}_{\alpha} as reference coordinate to determine λαsubscript𝜆𝛼\lambda_{\alpha}). The single-particle potentials VαR​e​ssubscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑅𝑒𝑠𝛼V^{Res}_{\alpha} (with R​e​s=0,1𝑅𝑒𝑠01Res=0,1) are the sums of all intermolecular potentials acting on particle α𝛼\alpha, properly normalized so that double counting is avoided. The term Vαintsubscriptsuperscript𝑉int𝛼V^{\textrm{int}}_{\alpha} represents all intramolecular interactions, such as bond and angle potentials, which are not subject to interpolation. The term Δ​HΔ𝐻\Delta H, referred to as the Free Energy Compensation (FEC) Potestio et al. (2013a, b), is an external field acting in the HY transition region to eliminate the density imbalance that naturally occurs in such dual-resolution systems. Different models of the same physical system exhibit a free energy difference that needs to be neutralized in order to enforce identical thermodynamical and/or structural properties (e.g. density) everywhere in the simulation domain. The FEC levels off these free energy imbalances. H-AdResS has been used mainly to couple atomistic and coarse-grained two-body force fields Potestio et al. (2013a, b); Kreis et al. (2015); Kreis and Potestio (2016). In general, however, the potentials can refer to any non-bonded interaction VαR​e​ssubscriptsuperscript𝑉𝑅𝑒𝑠𝛼V^{Res}_{\alpha}.

We have combined the mass-based quantum–classical interpolation with the H-AdResS scheme in order to enable use of different force fields within the QM and the CL regions. This can be advantageous, for example, when the CL region’s only role is that of a particle reservoir, in which case a very simple force field can be used in the CL region. On the other hand, when simulating a protein, for example, and only a small part of it needs to treat nuclear quantum effects explicitly, one would probably resort to the same force-field everywhere in the system and just “add” the nuclear quantum effects in the relevant region with the present quantum–classical multiresolution scheme.

Combining the quantum–classical mass interpolation and the H-AdResS scheme, we can write the Hamiltonian operator of N𝑁N interacting Boltzmann particles in three dimensions as Kreis et al. (2016a)

ℋ^=∑α=1N(12​𝐩^α​μ−1​(𝐫^α)​𝐩^α+VH-AdResS​(𝐫^α))^ℋsuperscriptsubscript𝛼1𝑁12subscript^𝐩𝛼superscript𝜇1subscript^𝐫𝛼subscript^𝐩𝛼superscript𝑉H-AdResSsubscript^𝐫𝛼\hat{\mathcal{H}}=\sum_{\alpha=1}^{N}\left(\frac{1}{2}\hat{\mathbf{p}}_{\alpha}\mu^{-1}(\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{\alpha})\hat{\mathbf{p}}_{\alpha}+V^{\textrm{H-AdResS}}(\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{\alpha})\right) (2)

where μ−1​(𝐫^α)superscript𝜇1subscript^𝐫𝛼\mu^{-1}(\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{\alpha}) is the inverse mass operator. The potential energy term VH-AdResS​(𝐫^α)superscript𝑉H-AdResSsubscript^𝐫𝛼V^{\textrm{H-AdResS}}(\hat{\mathbf{r}}_{\alpha}) corresponds to the interpolated H-AdResS potential energy, i.e. the term within the sum in Eq. 1. We have shown that PI quantization then leads to the following approximate expression for the partition function Kreis et al. (2016a) (the exact nature of the approximation will be discussed shortly):

with

where α𝛼\alpha indexes the different particles and k𝑘k the individual Trotter beads for each of them. A resolution value λα,ksubscript𝜆𝛼𝑘\lambda_{\alpha,k} is associated with each bead. We have renamed Vα,k0,1subscriptsuperscript𝑉01𝛼𝑘V^{0,1}_{\alpha,k} to Vα,kCL,QMsubscriptsuperscript𝑉CLQM𝛼𝑘V^{\textrm{CL},\textrm{QM}}_{\alpha,k} to emphasize that Vα,kCLsubscriptsuperscript𝑉CL𝛼𝑘V^{\textrm{CL}}_{\alpha,k} (Vα,kQMsubscriptsuperscript𝑉QM𝛼𝑘V^{\textrm{QM}}_{\alpha,k}) is the intermolecular potential acting in the CL (QM) region. Note that the normalization term in Eq. 3 depends on the position of the particles via μα,ksubscript𝜇𝛼𝑘\mu_{\alpha,k}. To obtain a constant normalization factor, one can transform this position dependent term to a potential energy in VPμsuperscriptsubscript𝑉𝑃𝜇V_{P}^{\mu}, as done in our previous article Kreis et al. (2016a), and then treat it as a constant field in the hybrid region. In this work, however, we will deal with it in a different way, which we will discuss in detail later.

The above expression (Eqs. 3 and 4) is consistent with a rigorous PI quantization if

|d​μ​(x)d​x|≪2​μ​(x)Λμ​(x)much-less-than𝑑𝜇𝑥𝑑𝑥2𝜇𝑥subscriptΛ𝜇𝑥\left|\frac{d\mu(x)}{dx}\right|\ll\frac{2\mu(x)}{\Lambda_{\mu}(x)} (5)

with Λμ​(x)≡β​ℏ2/(P​μ​(x))subscriptΛ𝜇𝑥𝛽superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi2𝑃𝜇𝑥\Lambda_{\mu}(x)\equiv\sqrt{\beta\hbar^{2}/(P\mu(x))}. A derivation of this condition was presented in Ref. Kreis et al., 2016a. This criterion indicates that the interpolation between the QM and the CL parts of the system must be sufficiently smooth such that the mass difference between two neighboring beads on a ring polymer in the HY region is negligible. This requirement can always be satisfied by choosing a sufficiently large HY region. Note, however, that even if Eq. 5 is not fulfilled, Eqs. 3 and 4 correspond to a well-defined quantum–classical simulation protocol.

The ring polymers described by the energy function VPμsuperscriptsubscript𝑉𝑃𝜇V_{P}^{\mu} (Eq. 4) are expanded in the region where the mass is small, and collapse to nearly classical point-like particles in the large-mass region. Therefore, in the CL region the interactions between different ring polymers do not need to be computed as an average over the P𝑃P bead pairs as done in the QM region. Instead, due to their nearly point-like structure, one can use only the centroid with negligible error (see Fig. 1). In this manner, classical computational efficiency is regained in the CL region.

III Quantum–classical path integral molecular dynamics

In our previous paper Kreis et al. (2016a), we validated the scheme introduced above via simulations of liquid parahydrogen using a basic Monte Carlo algorithm to directly sample the phase space defined by VPμsuperscriptsubscript𝑉𝑃𝜇V_{P}^{\mu}. A more state-of-the-art approach to the numerical evaluation of PIs is provided by PIMD, in which a thermostated dynamics is generated in phase space to sample the quantum canonical ensemble Chandler and Wolynes (1981); Parrinello and Rahman (1984); Hall and Berne (1984); Berne and Thirumalai (1986); Tuckerman et al. (1993); Martyna, Hughes, and Tuckerman (1999); Tuckerman (2010). PIMD is more easily parallelizable compared to Monte Carlo methods and therefore significantly more efficient for typical simulation setups and on multicore computer architectures. Moreover, PIMD is the method of choice for ab initio path integrals Marx and Parrinello (1996); Tuckerman et al. (1996). In the following, we show how the proposed quantum–classical multiresolution method can be implemented in PIMD as well as CMD and RPMD.

III.1 Evaluation of the adaptive mass and the resolution function on the centroids

In order to decouple the modes of the cyclic ring polymers from each other, PIMD is typically performed using staging variables Pollock and Ceperley (1984); Tuckerman et al. (1993) or, more popularly, normal modes Tuckerman et al. (1993); Cao and Voth (1994d). In our case, we cannot transform smoothly into normal mode space, because the beads of the individual ring polymers have different masses μα,ksubscript𝜇𝛼𝑘\mu_{\alpha,k} within the HY region. For typical systems like liquid water at room temperature, however, this mass difference is small as the extension of the ring polymers, measured by the root-mean-square radius of gyration rgsuperscript𝑟𝑔r^{g}, is short, even in the QM region. This suggests that we associate a single resolution value λαsubscript𝜆𝛼\lambda_{\alpha} and a single adaptive mass value μαsubscript𝜇𝛼\mu_{\alpha} with each atomic or molecular particle α𝛼\alpha instead of with every single bead k𝑘k. λαsubscript𝜆𝛼\lambda_{\alpha} and μαsubscript𝜇𝛼\mu_{\alpha} can then be determined using the ring polymer’s centroid positions.

Although this corresponds only to a minor modification in Eq. 4, we can ask to what extent the configurational energy VPμsuperscriptsubscript𝑉𝑃𝜇V_{P}^{\mu} is then still compatible with formal PI quantization. To this end, we first consider the adaptive mass μα,ksubscript𝜇𝛼𝑘\mu_{\alpha,k} of an individual Trotter bead within the HY region which we can approximate as

μα,k≈μαc+δ​xα,k​d​μ​(xαc)d​x,subscript𝜇𝛼𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑐𝛼𝛿subscript𝑥𝛼𝑘𝑑𝜇subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑐𝛼𝑑𝑥\mu_{\alpha,k}\approx\mu^{c}_{\alpha}+\delta x_{\alpha,k}\frac{d\mu(x^{c}_{\alpha})}{dx}, (6)

where xαcsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑐𝛼x^{c}_{\alpha} is the centroid coordinate along the direction of resolution change of the ring polymer α𝛼\alpha. For a setup where the resolution changes along the x-direction, this would be the centroid’s x𝑥x-coordinate and for a system where the QM region is spherical and the resolution changes radially, this would be the radial distance from the center. μαcsubscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑐𝛼\mu^{c}_{\alpha} is the mass function evaluated at the centroid xαcsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑐𝛼x^{c}_{\alpha} and δ​xα,k𝛿subscript𝑥𝛼𝑘\delta x_{\alpha,k} is the distance along the direction of resolution change between the k𝑘k-th bead of ring α𝛼\alpha and its centroid xαcsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑐𝛼x^{c}_{\alpha}. We have δ​xα,k≲rg​(xαc)less-than-or-similar-to𝛿subscript𝑥𝛼𝑘superscript𝑟𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑐𝛼\delta x_{\alpha,k}\lesssim r^{g}(x^{c}_{\alpha}), where rg​(x)=β​ℏ2/(4​μ​(x))⋅1−1/P2≈β​ℏ2/(4​μ​(x))superscript𝑟𝑔𝑥⋅𝛽superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi24𝜇𝑥11superscript𝑃2𝛽superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi24𝜇𝑥r^{g}(x)=\sqrt{\beta\hbar^{2}/(4\mu(x))}\cdot\sqrt{1-1/P^{2}}\approx\sqrt{\beta\hbar^{2}/(4\mu(x))} is the radius of gyration of a free ring with mass μ​(x)𝜇𝑥\mu(x) for large P𝑃P. Hence, we can approximate μα,k≈μαcsubscript𝜇𝛼𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑐𝛼\mu_{\alpha,k}\approx\mu^{c}_{\alpha} if

|d​μ​(xαc)d​x|≪μαcrg​(xαc),much-less-than𝑑𝜇subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑐𝛼𝑑𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑐𝛼superscript𝑟𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑐𝛼\left|\frac{d\mu(x^{c}_{\alpha})}{dx}\right|\ll\frac{\mu^{c}_{\alpha}}{r^{g}(x^{c}_{\alpha})}, (7)

or simply

|d​μ​(x)d​x|≪μ​(x)rg​(x).much-less-than𝑑𝜇𝑥𝑑𝑥𝜇𝑥superscript𝑟𝑔𝑥\left|\frac{d\mu(x)}{dx}\right|\ll\frac{\mu(x)}{r^{g}(x)}. (8)

for general x𝑥x. Here, we used the free ring-polymer radius of gyration. However, for the ring polymers in typical systems the average radius of gyration differs only slightly from the free-particle radius.

Eq. 8 is a slightly stronger criterion than that in Eq. 5. This makes sense, since Eq. 5 essentially provides the condition under which the mass can be considered as constant between two neighboring beads, while the new criterion, Eq. 8, gives the condition for treating the mass as constant over an entire ring polymer. For liquid water at room temperature, Eq. 8 is satisfied by a hybrid region wider than ≈1​nmabsent1nm\approx 1\,\text{nm}. An even smaller hybrid region would not be desirable anyway, since the interaction cutoffs of typical interaction potentials are also of the order ≈1​nmabsent1nm\approx 1\,\text{nm}.

Next, we consider the resolution λ𝜆\lambda itself, which we also seek to treat as constant over a whole ring polymer so that it can be approximated as a function of the centroid position only. On the one hand, λ𝜆\lambda varies between 0 and 1 and changes most steeply in the center of the HY region (see Fig. 1). On the other hand, an upper bound on the extension of the ring polymers is provided by the radius of gyration of the ring polymers in the QM region, which will be denoted as rQMgsuperscriptsubscript𝑟QM𝑔r_{\text{QM}}^{g}. Therefore, if the change in λ𝜆\lambda, corresponding to its gradient in the center of the HY region, over a distance rQMgsuperscriptsubscript𝑟QM𝑔r_{\text{QM}}^{g} is much smaller than ≈1absent1\approx 1, we can approximate λα,k≈λαcsubscript𝜆𝛼𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑐𝛼\lambda_{\alpha,k}\approx\lambda^{c}_{\alpha} everywhere (as for the adaptive mass before, λαcsubscriptsuperscript𝜆𝑐𝛼\lambda^{c}_{\alpha} denotes the resolution function of ring α𝛼\alpha evaluated at its centroid xαcsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑐𝛼x^{c}_{\alpha}). This corresponds to

|(d​λ​(x)d​x|x=​dHY/2)|rQMg≪1,\left|\left(\frac{d\lambda(x)}{dx}\bigg{|}_{x_{=}d_{\text{HY}}/2}\right)\right|r^{g}_{\text{QM}}\ll 1, (9)

where d​λ​(x)/d​x|x=dHY/2evaluated-at𝑑𝜆𝑥𝑑𝑥𝑥subscript𝑑HY2d\lambda(x)/dx|_{x=d_{\text{HY}}/2} denotes the gradient of λ𝜆\lambda in the center of the HY region and dHYsubscript𝑑HYd_{\text{HY}} the width of the HY region. The criterion in Eq. 9 can be easily fulfilled for typical systems such as water at room temperature, with a HY region of width dHY≈1​nmsubscript𝑑HY1nmd_{\text{HY}}\approx 1\,\text{nm}.

To summarize, in the following we will treat both the mass and the resolution as a constant over entire ring polymers and write, for simplicity, μα,k​(x)→μα​(x)→subscript𝜇𝛼𝑘𝑥subscript𝜇𝛼𝑥\mu_{\alpha,k}(x)\rightarrow\mu_{\alpha}(x) and λα,k​(x)→λα​(x)→subscript𝜆𝛼𝑘𝑥subscript𝜆𝛼𝑥\lambda_{\alpha,k}(x)\rightarrow\lambda_{\alpha}(x), where we assume that the mass and the resolution functions for an atom α𝛼\alpha have been evaluated using its centroid coordinate xαcsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑐𝛼x^{c}_{\alpha} and that the resulting parameters have been assigned to all beads belonging to ring α𝛼\alpha. Then we can write the partition function as

Q=limP→∞[∏k=1P∏α=1N∫d​𝐫α,k​(μα​P2​π​β​ℏ2)32]​e−β​V~Pμ𝑄subscript→𝑃delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑃superscriptsubscriptproduct𝛼1𝑁dsubscript𝐫𝛼𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜇𝛼𝑃2𝜋𝛽superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi232superscript𝑒𝛽superscriptsubscript~𝑉𝑃𝜇Q=\lim\limits_{P\to\infty}\left[\prod_{k=1}^{P}\prod_{\alpha=1}^{N}\int\text{d}{\mathbf{r}}_{\alpha,k}\left(\frac{\mu_{\alpha}P}{2\pi\beta\hbar^{2}}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}\right]e^{-\beta\tilde{V}_{P}^{\mu}} (10)

with

V~Pμsuperscriptsubscript~𝑉𝑃𝜇\displaystyle\tilde{V}_{P}^{\mu} =\displaystyle= ∑k=1P∑α=1N{μα​ωP22|𝐫α,k−𝐫α,k+1|2\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{P}\ \sum_{\alpha=1}^{N}\left\{\frac{\mu_{\alpha}\ \omega_{P}^{2}}{2}|{\mathbf{r}}_{\alpha,k}-{\mathbf{r}}_{\alpha,k+1}|^{2}\right. (11)
+\displaystyle+ 1P[λαVα,kQM+(1−λα)Vα,kCL+Vα,kint−ΔH(𝐫αc)]},\displaystyle\left.\frac{1}{P}\left[\lambda_{\alpha}V^{\textrm{QM}}_{\alpha,k}+(1-\lambda_{\alpha})V^{\textrm{CL}}_{\alpha,k}+V^{\textrm{int}}_{\alpha,k}-\Delta H(\mathbf{r}^{c}_{\alpha})\right]\right\},

where 𝐫αcsubscriptsuperscript𝐫𝑐𝛼\mathbf{r}^{c}_{\alpha} denotes the centroid of ring polymer α𝛼\alpha. Note that the FEC is now also applied at the single-atom, i.e., centroid level. The criteria in Eqs. 8 and 9 quantify the degree to which this partition function is still compatible with a formal, bottom-up PI quantization. The inequalities can always be fulfilled by choosing a sufficiently wide hybrid region. However, even if they are not met, the final partition function, Eqs. 10 and 11, still represents a well-defined Hamiltonian multiresolution quantum–classical simulation scheme.

III.2 Introducing normal modes

Now that the different beads of each ring polymer α𝛼\alpha all have the same adaptive mass μαsubscript𝜇𝛼\mu_{\alpha}, we can proceed with transforming the Cartesian coordinates into normal modes 𝐮α,ksubscript𝐮𝛼𝑘\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,k} via

𝐮α,k=∑j=1P𝐫α,j​Cj​k,subscript𝐮𝛼𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑗1subscript𝐫𝛼𝑗subscript𝐶𝑗𝑘\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,k}=\sum^{P}_{j=1}\mathbf{r}_{\alpha,j}C_{jk}, (12)

where, for even P𝑃P, the orthogonal transformation matrix is Ceriotti et al. (2010)

Cj​k={1/Pif ​k=12/P​cos​(2​π​j​k/P)if ​2≤k≤P/21/P​(−1)jif ​k=P/2+12/P​sin​(2​π​j​k/P)if ​P/2+2≤k≤Psubscript𝐶𝑗𝑘cases1𝑃if 𝑘12𝑃cos2𝜋𝑗𝑘𝑃if 2𝑘𝑃21𝑃superscript1𝑗if 𝑘𝑃212𝑃sin2𝜋𝑗𝑘𝑃if 𝑃22𝑘𝑃C_{jk}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\sqrt{1/P}&\mbox{if }k=1\\ \sqrt{2/P}\,\textrm{cos}(2\pi jk/P)&\mbox{if }2\leq k\leq P/2\\ \sqrt{1/P}\,(-1)^{j}&\mbox{if }k=P/2+1\\ \sqrt{2/P}\,\textrm{sin}(2\pi jk/P)&\mbox{if }P/2+2\leq k\leq P\end{array}\right. (13)

such that for a given ring polymer at position x𝑥x:

μα​(x)​∑k=1P|𝐫α,k−𝐫α,k+1|2=μα​(x)​∑l=1Pξk​𝐮α,k2subscript𝜇𝛼𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝐫𝛼𝑘subscript𝐫𝛼𝑘12subscript𝜇𝛼𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑃subscript𝜉𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝐮2𝛼𝑘\mu_{\alpha}(x)\sum_{k=1}^{P}|{\mathbf{r}}_{\alpha,k}-{\mathbf{r}}_{\alpha,k+1}|^{2}=\mu_{\alpha}(x)\sum_{l=1}^{P}\xi_{k}\mathbf{u}^{2}_{\alpha,k} (14)

In normal mode representation, the centroid of a ring polymer α𝛼\alpha is given by the rescaled first mode coordinate, this is

rαc=1P​∑k=1Prα,k=1P​𝐮α,1.superscriptsubscriptr𝛼𝑐1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑃subscriptr𝛼𝑘1𝑃subscript𝐮𝛼1\textbf{r}_{\alpha}^{c}=\frac{1}{P}\sum_{k=1}^{P}\textbf{r}_{\alpha,k}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{P}}\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,1}. (16)

Therefore, the adaptive mass μαsubscript𝜇𝛼\mu_{\alpha} and the resolution function λαsubscript𝜆𝛼\lambda_{\alpha}, being evaluated at the centroids, are functions of the first mode only, i.e. μα​(rαc)=μα​(1/P​𝐮α,1)subscript𝜇𝛼superscriptsubscriptr𝛼𝑐subscript𝜇𝛼1𝑃subscript𝐮𝛼1\mu_{\alpha}(\textbf{r}_{\alpha}^{c})=\mu_{\alpha}(1/\sqrt{P}\,\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,1}) and λα​(rαc)=λα​(1/P​𝐮α,1)subscript𝜆𝛼superscriptsubscriptr𝛼𝑐subscript𝜆𝛼1𝑃subscript𝐮𝛼1\lambda_{\alpha}(\textbf{r}_{\alpha}^{c})=\lambda_{\alpha}(1/\sqrt{P}\,\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,1}). To lighten the notation, though, we will drop the 1/P1𝑃1/\sqrt{P} factor and write simply μα=μα​(𝐮α,1)subscript𝜇𝛼subscript𝜇𝛼subscript𝐮𝛼1\mu_{\alpha}=\mu_{\alpha}(\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,1}) and λα=λα​(𝐮α,1)subscript𝜆𝛼subscript𝜆𝛼subscript𝐮𝛼1\lambda_{\alpha}=\lambda_{\alpha}(\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,1}).

We then obtain the following partition function

Q=limP→∞[∏k=1P∏α=1N∫d​𝐮α,k​(μα​(𝐮α,1)​P2​π​β​ℏ2)32]​e−β​V~Pμ𝑄subscript→𝑃delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑃superscriptsubscriptproduct𝛼1𝑁dsubscript𝐮𝛼𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜇𝛼subscript𝐮𝛼1𝑃2𝜋𝛽superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi232superscript𝑒𝛽superscriptsubscript~𝑉𝑃𝜇Q=\lim\limits_{P\to\infty}\left[\prod_{k=1}^{P}\prod_{\alpha=1}^{N}\int\text{d}{\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,k}\left(\frac{\mu_{\alpha}(\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,1})P}{2\pi\beta\hbar^{2}}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}\right]e^{-\beta\tilde{V}_{P}^{\mu}} (17)

and the rescaled adaptive mass να,k​(𝐮α,1)=μα​(𝐮α,1)​ξksubscript𝜈𝛼𝑘subscript𝐮𝛼1subscript𝜇𝛼subscript𝐮𝛼1subscript𝜉𝑘\nu_{\alpha,k}(\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,1})=\mu_{\alpha}(\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,1})\,\xi_{k}. For the centroid, i.e. k=1𝑘1k=1, we have να,k​(𝐮α,1)=0subscript𝜈𝛼𝑘subscript𝐮𝛼10\nu_{\alpha,k}(\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,1})=0. In Eqs. 17 and 18, we have explicitly indicated the dependencies of the different terms on the normal modes. The notation 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u} without any indices is a shorthand for the compound set of all coordinates 𝐮α,ksubscript𝐮𝛼𝑘\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,k}.

III.3 Introducing momenta

In PIMD, one usually recasts the prefactor of the partition function as Gaussian integrals over a set of variables that can be interpreted as momenta conjugate to the coordinates 𝐮α,ksubscript𝐮𝛼𝑘\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,k} Tuckerman (2010). The energy term in the exponential can then be interpreted as a classical Hamiltonian and sampled via thermostated molecular dynamics. In our case, however, the prefactor is position dependent and, therefore, we have different options to proceed.

(a) Constant kinetic masses. As was done in our previous article Kreis et al. (2016a), we can write

(μα​(𝐮α,1)​P2​π​β​ℏ2)32=(m~​P2​π​β​ℏ2)32​exp⁡{−β​(−32​β​log⁡(μα​(𝐮α,1)m~))}superscriptsubscript𝜇𝛼subscript𝐮𝛼1𝑃2𝜋𝛽superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi232superscript~𝑚𝑃2𝜋𝛽superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi232𝛽32𝛽subscript𝜇𝛼subscript𝐮𝛼1~𝑚\left(\frac{\mu_{\alpha}(\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,1})P}{2\pi\beta\hbar^{2}}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}=\left(\frac{\tilde{m}P}{2\pi\beta\hbar^{2}}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}\exp\left\{-\beta\left(-\frac{3}{2\beta}\log\left(\frac{\mu_{\alpha}(\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,1})}{\tilde{m}}\right)\right)\right\} (19)

where we used an arbitrary mass m~~𝑚\tilde{m} as the reference mass scale. Then we can pull the term −(3/2​β)​log⁡(μα/m~)32𝛽subscript𝜇𝛼~𝑚-(3/2\beta)\,\log\left(\mu_{\alpha}/\tilde{m}\right) into V~Pμsuperscriptsubscript~𝑉𝑃𝜇\tilde{V}_{P}^{\mu} as an external field in the HY region and use the now constant prefactor to introduce a set of momenta via rephrasing the prefactor as Gaussian integrals. This yields

Q=limP→∞[∏k=1P∏α=1N∫d​𝐮α,k​∫d​𝐩α,k]​e−β​HPckm𝑄subscript→𝑃delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑃superscriptsubscriptproduct𝛼1𝑁dsubscript𝐮𝛼𝑘dsubscript𝐩𝛼𝑘superscript𝑒𝛽superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑃ckmQ=\lim\limits_{P\to\infty}\left[\prod_{k=1}^{P}\prod_{\alpha=1}^{N}\int\text{d}{\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,k}\int\text{d}{\mathbf{p}}_{\alpha,k}\right]e^{-\beta H_{P}^{\textrm{ckm}}} (20)

with the Hamiltonian

HPckm=∑k=1P∑α=1N{𝐩α,k22​mα,k′+12να,kωP2𝐮α,k2−32​P​βlogμα​(𝐮α,1)m~++1P[λα(𝐮α,1)Vα,kQM(𝐮)+(1−λα(𝐮α,1))Vα,kCL(𝐮)+Vα,kint(𝐮)−ΔH(𝐮α,1)]}.superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑃ckmsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝛼1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐩𝛼𝑘22subscriptsuperscript𝑚′𝛼𝑘12subscript𝜈𝛼𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑃2superscriptsubscript𝐮𝛼𝑘232𝑃𝛽subscript𝜇𝛼subscript𝐮𝛼1~𝑚1𝑃delimited-[]subscript𝜆𝛼subscript𝐮𝛼1subscriptsuperscript𝑉QM𝛼𝑘𝐮1subscript𝜆𝛼subscript𝐮𝛼1subscriptsuperscript𝑉CL𝛼𝑘𝐮subscriptsuperscript𝑉int𝛼𝑘𝐮Δ𝐻subscript𝐮𝛼1\begin{split}H_{P}^{\textrm{ckm}}=&\sum_{k=1}^{P}\ \sum_{\alpha=1}^{N}\left\{\frac{{\mathbf{p}}_{\alpha,k}^{2}}{2m^{\prime}_{\alpha,k}}+\frac{1}{2}\nu_{\alpha,k}\omega_{P}^{2}{\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,k}^{2}-\frac{3}{2P\beta}\log{\frac{\mu_{\alpha}({\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,1})}{\tilde{m}}}+\right.\\ &\left.+\frac{1}{P}\left[\lambda_{\alpha}({\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,1})V^{\textrm{QM}}_{\alpha,k}({\mathbf{u}})+\left(1-\lambda_{\alpha}({\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,1})\right)V^{\textrm{CL}}_{\alpha,k}({\mathbf{u}})+V^{\textrm{int}}_{\alpha,k}({\mathbf{u}})-\Delta H\left({\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,1}\right)\right]\right\}.\end{split} (21)

As the additional logarithmic term only acts as an external field in the HY region, it can be exactly removed via the FEC function Δ​HΔ𝐻\Delta H. We will denote the fictitious masses mα,k′subscriptsuperscript𝑚′𝛼𝑘m^{\prime}_{\alpha,k} in the following as “kinetic” masses in contrast to να,ksubscript𝜈𝛼𝑘\nu_{\alpha,k}, which we will refer to as spring masses. In principle, the set of mα,k′subscriptsuperscript𝑚′𝛼𝑘m^{\prime}_{\alpha,k} can be chosen freely, as their rescaling does not affect thermodynamic averages Tuckerman (2010).

HPckmsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑃ckmH_{P}^{\textrm{ckm}} in Eq. 21 defines a classical Hamiltonian system composed of ring polymers representing the delocalized atoms. In the QM region where λα=1subscript𝜆𝛼1\lambda_{\alpha}=1 and μα=msubscript𝜇𝛼𝑚\mu_{\alpha}=m, the ring polymers are extended and the regular quantum mechanical behaviour is recovered. In the CL region where λα=0subscript𝜆𝛼0\lambda_{\alpha}=0 and μα=Msubscript𝜇𝛼𝑀\mu_{\alpha}=M the ring polymers are collapsed to essentially point-like particles, thereby reproducing classical mechanics. The Hamiltonian gives rise to regular equations of motion that can be integrated by a symplectic integrator such as the velocity Verlet algorithm Tuckerman (2010), with the possibility of employing multiple time-stepping.

However, let us take a closer look at the different masses in the system. While the spring masses να,ksubscript𝜈𝛼𝑘\nu_{\alpha,k} change between the CL and QM subregions of the system, the kinetic masses mα,k′subscriptsuperscript𝑚′𝛼𝑘m^{\prime}_{\alpha,k} do not. We choose mα,k′=mα/Psubscriptsuperscript𝑚′𝛼𝑘subscript𝑚𝛼𝑃m^{\prime}_{\alpha,k}=m_{\alpha}/P with mαsubscript𝑚𝛼m_{\alpha} being the real mass of atom α𝛼\alpha, since this corresponds to a realistic bead-wise approximate quantum dynamical behavior in the QM region similar to RPMD (in RPMD one usually chooses mα,k′=mαsubscriptsuperscript𝑚′𝛼𝑘subscript𝑚𝛼m^{\prime}_{\alpha,k}=m_{\alpha} without 1/P1𝑃1/P, but rescales the potential energy terms by P𝑃P and runs the simulation at a P𝑃P-times higher temperature Craig and Manolopoulos (2004); Braams and Manolopoulos (2006); Hone, Rossky, and Voth (2006); Pérez, Tuckerman, and Müser (2009); Habershon et al. (2013); Rossi, Ceriotti, and Manolopoulos (2014). Here, the factor of 1/P1𝑃1/P in the mass is equivalent to this procedure, as we perform the simulations at the actual temperature and use a Hamiltonian, Eq. 21, without rescaling potential energies). Therefore, in the QM region, the modes oscillate with vibration frequencies ωP​ξk​Psubscript𝜔𝑃subscript𝜉𝑘𝑃\omega_{P}\sqrt{\xi_{k}P}. In the CL region, however, where να,ksubscript𝜈𝛼𝑘\nu_{\alpha,k} is significantly larger than in the QM subsystem the modes oscillate faster than in the QM region by a factor of Mα/mαsubscript𝑀𝛼subscript𝑚𝛼\sqrt{M_{\alpha}/m_{\alpha}}. For the case of Mα=100​mαsubscript𝑀𝛼100subscript𝑚𝛼M_{\alpha}=100\,m_{\alpha}, this results in 10 times higher frequencies. This would require a 10 times smaller time step in the integration algorithm compared to a normal quantum simulation or compared to what would be required in the QM subregion. Although this poses no fundamental hurdle, it may slow down the simulations notably.

(b) Adaptive kinetic masses. The previous observation suggests an alternative approach: We can also directly recast the prefactor as a Gaussian integral, which includes the position dependent mass μαsubscript𝜇𝛼\mu_{\alpha},

(μα​(𝐮α,1)​P2​π​β​ℏ2)32=(P24​π2​ℏ2)32​∫𝑑𝒑α,k​exp⁡{−β​P​𝒑α,k22​μα​(𝐮α,1)}.superscriptsubscript𝜇𝛼subscript𝐮𝛼1𝑃2𝜋𝛽superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi232superscriptsuperscript𝑃24superscript𝜋2superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi232differential-dsubscript𝒑𝛼𝑘𝛽𝑃superscriptsubscript𝒑𝛼𝑘22subscript𝜇𝛼subscript𝐮𝛼1\left(\frac{\mu_{\alpha}(\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,1})P}{2\pi\beta\hbar^{2}}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}=\left(\frac{P^{2}}{4\pi^{2}\hbar^{2}}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}\int d\bm{p}_{\alpha,k}\exp\left\{-\beta P\,\frac{\bm{p}_{\alpha,k}^{2}}{2\mu_{\alpha}(\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,1})}\right\}. (22)

In this way, we can introduce a kinetic energy term which has adaptive kinetic masses. This leads to the construction of a Hamiltonian in which both the spring and the kinetic masses vary in the same fashion, such that the modes oscillate with the same frequencies everywhere in the quantum–classical adaptive resolution setup.

Specifically, we propose the following: Overall, we have N×P𝑁𝑃N\times P prefactors of the form

(μα​(𝐮α,1)​P2​π​β​ℏ2)32,superscriptsubscript𝜇𝛼subscript𝐮𝛼1𝑃2𝜋𝛽superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-pi232\left(\frac{\mu_{\alpha}(\mathbf{u}_{\alpha,1})P}{2\pi\beta\hbar^{2}}\right)^{\frac{3}{2}}, (23)

one for each atom and mode. For all higher modes with k>1𝑘1k>1, we transform the prefactors according to Eq. 22 and introduce the momentum terms in the Hamiltonian with a variable mass in the denominator. The remaining N𝑁N prefactors are then treated via Eq. 19, and the kinetic masses for the centroid modes, which are not associated with springs since να,1=0subscript𝜈𝛼10\nu_{\alpha,1}=0, are chosen constant. We then obtain

Q=limP→∞[∏k=1P∏α=1N∫d​𝐮α,k​∫d​𝐩α,k]​e−β​HPakm𝑄subscript→𝑃delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑃superscriptsubscriptproduct𝛼1𝑁dsubscript𝐮𝛼𝑘dsubscript𝐩𝛼𝑘superscript𝑒𝛽superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑃akmQ=\lim\limits_{P\to\infty}\left[\prod_{k=1}^{P}\prod_{\alpha=1}^{N}\int\text{d}{\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,k}\int\text{d}{\mathbf{p}}_{\alpha,k}\right]e^{-\beta H_{P}^{\textrm{akm}}} (24)

with the Hamiltonian

HPakm=∑k=1P∑α=1N{𝐩α,k22​να,k′​(𝐮α,1)+12να,kωP2𝐮α,k2−32​P​βlogμα​(𝐮α,1)m~++1P[λα(𝐮α,1)Vα,kQM(𝐮)+(1−λα(𝐮α,1))Vα,kCL(𝐮)+Vα,kint(𝐮)−ΔH(𝐮α,1)]},superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑃akmsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝛼1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐩𝛼𝑘22subscriptsuperscript𝜈′𝛼𝑘subscript𝐮𝛼112subscript𝜈𝛼𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑃2superscriptsubscript𝐮𝛼𝑘232𝑃𝛽subscript𝜇𝛼subscript𝐮𝛼1~𝑚1𝑃delimited-[]subscript𝜆𝛼subscript𝐮𝛼1subscriptsuperscript𝑉QM𝛼𝑘𝐮1subscript𝜆𝛼subscript𝐮𝛼1subscriptsuperscript𝑉CL𝛼𝑘𝐮subscriptsuperscript𝑉int𝛼𝑘𝐮Δ𝐻subscript𝐮𝛼1\begin{split}H_{P}^{\textrm{akm}}=&\sum_{k=1}^{P}\ \sum_{\alpha=1}^{N}\left\{\frac{{\mathbf{p}}_{\alpha,k}^{2}}{2\nu^{\prime}_{\alpha,k}({\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,1})}+\frac{1}{2}\nu_{\alpha,k}\omega_{P}^{2}{\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,k}^{2}-\frac{3}{2P\beta}\log{\frac{\mu_{\alpha}({\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,1})}{\tilde{m}}}+\right.\\ &\left.+\frac{1}{P}\left[\lambda_{\alpha}({\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,1})V^{\textrm{QM}}_{\alpha,k}({\mathbf{u}})+\left(1-\lambda_{\alpha}({\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,1})\right)V^{\textrm{CL}}_{\alpha,k}({\mathbf{u}})+V^{\textrm{int}}_{\alpha,k}({\mathbf{u}})-\Delta H\left({\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,1}\right)\right]\right\},\end{split} (25)

where να,k′subscriptsuperscript𝜈′𝛼𝑘\nu^{\prime}_{\alpha,k} is the kinetic mass of bead k𝑘k of atom α𝛼\alpha. Note that a 1/P1𝑃1/P factor appears in front of the logarithmic term in HPakmsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑃akmH_{P}^{\textrm{akm}} because the term still appears in the sum over all P𝑃P, although we obtain the logarithmic term only for the centroid modes. Choosing appropriate prefactors, the parameters να,k′subscriptsuperscript𝜈′𝛼𝑘\nu^{\prime}_{\alpha,k} are

να,1′=subscriptsuperscript𝜈′𝛼1absent\displaystyle\nu^{\prime}_{\alpha,1}= mα/P,subscript𝑚𝛼𝑃\displaystyle m_{\alpha}/P, k=1, centroid mode,𝑘1 centroid mode\displaystyle\qquad k=1,\textrm{ centroid mode}, (26)
να,k′=subscriptsuperscript𝜈′𝛼𝑘absent\displaystyle\nu^{\prime}_{\alpha,k}= ν~α=μα/P,subscript~𝜈𝛼subscript𝜇𝛼𝑃\displaystyle\tilde{\nu}_{\alpha}=\mu_{\alpha}/P, k>1, higher modes.𝑘1 higher modes\displaystyle\qquad k>1,\textrm{ higher modes}. (27)

Since the kinetic masses for the higher modes are all equal, we introduced a new abbreviation, ν~αsubscript~𝜈𝛼\tilde{\nu}_{\alpha}, for them without the index k𝑘k. We choose a factor 1/P1𝑃1/P to ensure that the approximate quantum dynamical time evolution of the centroids proceeds on the real timescale, that is, the same as in corresponding classical Newtonian dynamics. As already pointed out, this choice is equivalent to the temperature rescaling often done in ring polymer molecular dynamics Craig and Manolopoulos (2004); Braams and Manolopoulos (2006); Hone, Rossky, and Voth (2006); Pérez, Tuckerman, and Müser (2009); Habershon et al. (2013); Rossi, Ceriotti, and Manolopoulos (2014), which we do not perform here. A further rescaling of the kinetic masses would be allowed when sampling only canonical averages Tuckerman (2010); Tuckerman et al. (1993).

We can interpret the choice of the kinetic masses in the following way: While moving from the QM to the CL via the HY region, the spring constants of the higher modes become stronger and the ring polymers collapse. Simultaneously, however, these higher modes become heavier such that they do not vibrate faster in the CL region than in the QM region, despite the stiffer springs. Their oscillation frequencies are the same everywhere in the system such that their configurations can be sampled efficiently throughout the whole system with the same time step. The centroid modes do not undergo such oscillations, as they represent only the displacements of the ring polymers as a whole. Hence, their masses do not need to change across the transition from the QM to the CL part of the system and, therefore, they are chosen to be the real masses.

In the following we will refer to the constant kinetic mass (CKM) approach, defined by the Hamiltonian HPckmsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑃ckmH_{P}^{\textrm{ckm}} in Eq. 21, as the CKM approach and to the adaptive kinetic mass (AKM) scheme, defined by the Hamiltonian HPakmsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑃akmH_{P}^{\textrm{akm}} in Eq. 25, as the AKM approach.

III.4 Equations of motion

We will not discuss the equations of motion obtained in the CKM approach, as they resemble a regular structure that can be integrated, for example, by a regular velocity Verlet algorithm Tuckerman (2010). Instead, we focus on the AKM scheme, from which the CKM approach can be obtained as a special case.

In the following, we will assume that the logarithmic term in the Hamiltonian in Eq. 25 has been exactly canceled by an appropriately chosen FEC function Δ​H​(λ)Δ𝐻𝜆\Delta H(\lambda) and therefore omit it to simplify the notation.

The equations of motion then read as follows:

𝒖˙α,1=𝒑α,1να,1′​(𝒖α,1)=P​𝒑α,1mα,k=1, centroid mode,formulae-sequencesubscript˙𝒖𝛼1subscript𝒑𝛼1subscriptsuperscript𝜈′𝛼1subscript𝒖𝛼1𝑃subscript𝒑𝛼1subscript𝑚𝛼𝑘1 centroid mode,\dot{\bm{u}}_{\alpha,1}=\frac{\bm{p}_{\alpha,1}}{\nu^{\prime}_{\alpha,1}(\bm{u}_{\alpha,1})}=P\frac{\bm{p}_{\alpha,1}}{m_{\alpha}},\qquad k=1,\textrm{ centroid mode,} (28)
𝒖˙α,k=𝒑α,kν~α​(𝒖α,1)=P​𝒑α,kμα​(𝒖α,1),k>1, higher modes,formulae-sequencesubscript˙𝒖𝛼𝑘subscript𝒑𝛼𝑘subscript~𝜈𝛼subscript𝒖𝛼1𝑃subscript𝒑𝛼𝑘subscript𝜇𝛼subscript𝒖𝛼1𝑘1 higher modes,\dot{\bm{u}}_{\alpha,k}=\frac{\bm{p}_{\alpha,k}}{\tilde{\nu}_{\alpha}(\bm{u}_{\alpha,1})}=P\frac{\bm{p}_{\alpha,k}}{\mu_{\alpha}(\bm{u}_{\alpha,1})},\qquad k>1,\textrm{ higher modes,} (29)
𝒑˙α,1=𝐅α,1H-AdResS​(𝐮)−1P​[∑i=1P{Vα,iQM​(𝒖)−Vα,iCL​(𝒖)}]​∇𝒖α,1λ​(𝒖α,1)(𝐅1drift)−[∑i=2P12​(Mα−mα)P​ν~α​(𝒖α,1)2​𝒑α,i2]​∇𝒖α,1λ​(𝒖α,1)(𝐅2drift)−[∑i=2P12​ξi​(mα−Mα)​ωP2​𝐮α,i2]​∇𝒖α,1λ​(𝒖α,1)(𝐅3drift)+∇𝒖α,1Δ​H​(𝒖α,1),k=1, centroid mode,\begin{split}\dot{\bm{p}}_{\alpha,1}&=\mathbf{F}^{\textrm{H-AdResS}}_{\alpha,1}(\mathbf{u})\\ &-\frac{1}{P}\left[\sum_{i=1}^{P}\left\{V^{\textrm{QM}}_{\alpha,i}(\bm{u})-V^{\textrm{CL}}_{\alpha,i}(\bm{u})\right\}\right]\bm{\nabla}_{\bm{u}_{\alpha,1}}\lambda(\bm{u}_{\alpha,1})\qquad\qquad(\mathbf{F}_{1}^{\textrm{drift}})\\ &-\left[\sum_{i=2}^{P}\frac{1}{2}\frac{(M_{\alpha}-m_{\alpha})}{P\tilde{\nu}_{\alpha}(\bm{u}_{\alpha,1})^{2}}\bm{p}_{\alpha,i}^{2}\right]\bm{\nabla}_{\bm{u}_{\alpha,1}}\lambda(\bm{u}_{\alpha,1})\qquad\qquad\qquad(\mathbf{F}_{2}^{\textrm{drift}})\\ &-\left[\sum_{i=2}^{P}\frac{1}{2}\xi_{i}(m_{\alpha}-M_{\alpha})\omega_{P}^{2}{\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,i}^{2}\right]\bm{\nabla}_{\bm{u}_{\alpha,1}}\lambda(\bm{u}_{\alpha,1})\qquad\qquad\qquad(\mathbf{F}_{3}^{\textrm{drift}})\\ &+\bm{\nabla}_{\bm{u}_{\alpha,1}}\Delta H(\bm{u}_{\alpha,1}),\\ &\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad k=1,\textrm{ centroid mode,}\end{split} (30)
𝒑˙α,k=−να,k​(𝒖α,1)​ωP2​𝐮α,k+𝐅α,kH-AdResS​(𝐮),k>1, higher modes,formulae-sequencesubscript˙𝒑𝛼𝑘subscript𝜈𝛼𝑘subscript𝒖𝛼1superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑃2subscript𝐮𝛼𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝐅H-AdResS𝛼𝑘𝐮𝑘1 higher modes,\dot{\bm{p}}_{\alpha,k}=-\nu_{\alpha,k}(\bm{u}_{\alpha,1})\omega_{P}^{2}{\mathbf{u}}_{\alpha,k}+\mathbf{F}^{\textrm{H-AdResS}}_{\alpha,k}(\mathbf{u}),\qquad k>1,\textrm{ higher modes,} (31)

where

𝐅α,kH-AdResS​(𝐮)=−1P​∑j=1P∑β=1N[λβ​∇𝒖α,kVβ,jQM​(𝐮)+(1−λβ)​∇𝒖α,kVβ,jCL​(𝐮)+∇𝒖α,kVβ,jint​(𝐮)].subscriptsuperscript𝐅H-AdResS𝛼𝑘𝐮1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝛽1𝑁delimited-[]subscript𝜆𝛽subscriptbold-∇subscript𝒖𝛼𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑉QM𝛽𝑗𝐮1subscript𝜆𝛽subscriptbold-∇subscript𝒖𝛼𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑉CL𝛽𝑗𝐮subscriptbold-∇subscript𝒖𝛼𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑉int𝛽𝑗𝐮\mathbf{F}^{\textrm{H-AdResS}}_{\alpha,k}(\mathbf{u})=-\frac{1}{P}\sum_{j=1}^{P}\ \sum_{\beta=1}^{N}\left[\lambda_{\beta}\bm{\nabla}_{\bm{u}_{\alpha,k}}V^{\textrm{QM}}_{\beta,j}({\mathbf{u}})+\left(1-\lambda_{\beta}\right)\bm{\nabla}_{\bm{u}_{\alpha,k}}V^{\textrm{CL}}_{\beta,j}({\mathbf{u}})+\bm{\nabla}_{\bm{u}_{\alpha,k}}V^{\textrm{int}}_{\beta,j}({\mathbf{u}})\right]. (32)

The terms in lines 2-5 in Eq. 30 stem from the application of the derivative on the position dependent resolution function. The terms 𝐅idriftsuperscriptsubscript𝐅𝑖drift\mathbf{F}_{i}^{\textrm{drift}} are undesired forces that act only in the hybrid region, can lead to thermodynamic imbalances in the system, and, for example, artificially push particles from one subregion of the system to the other. In accordance with earlier works using the H-AdResS scheme, we will refer to these forces as drift forces Potestio et al. (2013a). They need to be compensated, which can be achieved via the FEC, line 5 in Eq. 30. In fact, the latter is typically constructed to cancel their average effect Potestio et al. (2013a, b); Español et al. (2015).

The drift force 𝐅1driftsuperscriptsubscript𝐅1drift\mathbf{F}_{1}^{\textrm{drift}} comes from the potential energy interpolation and would not be present if we changed only the masses of the atoms but not the force field. 𝐅2driftsuperscriptsubscript𝐅2drift\mathbf{F}_{2}^{\textrm{drift}} is a result of choosing the kinetic masses of the higher modes to be adaptive and would be absent in the CKM approach. Finally, 𝐅3driftsuperscriptsubscript𝐅3drift\mathbf{F}_{3}^{\textrm{drift}} corresponds to the adaptive spring masses. As the resolution λαsubscript𝜆𝛼\lambda_{\alpha} and the adaptive mass μαsubscript𝜇𝛼\mu_{\alpha} depend only on the centroid positions of the ring polymers, drift forces only occur in the equations of motion for the centroid. Therefore, the internal motion of the ring polymers is not disturbed by any drift forces and can smoothly change from quantum to classical and vice versa when the atoms move through the system. Only the translation of the ring polymers is affected by drift forces, which can be corrected via the FEC. Note that the sums in 𝐅2driftsuperscriptsubscript𝐅2drift\mathbf{F}_{2}^{\textrm{drift}} and 𝐅3driftsuperscriptsubscript𝐅3drift\mathbf{F}_{3}^{\textrm{drift}} only run over non-centroid modes, since the centroid mode neither appears in the spring constant term in the Hamiltonian, nor is it associated with a variable mass in the kinetic energy onto which the position derivative could act.

III.5 Integration

To devise a suitable integration scheme for the equations of motion, Eqs. 28-31, we use the Liouville operator formalism. To simplify the notation, in the following we will drop the atom index α𝛼\alpha, as the Liouville operators for different ring polymers, commute and do not require further discussion.

The Liouville operator i​L𝑖𝐿iL can be written as

i​L=i​L(1)+i​L(2),𝑖𝐿𝑖superscript𝐿1𝑖superscript𝐿2iL=iL^{(1)}+iL^{(2)}, (33)

where i​L(1)𝑖superscript𝐿1iL^{(1)} propagates positions and i​L(2)𝑖superscript𝐿2iL^{(2)} momenta. We further decompose

i​L(2)𝑖superscript𝐿2\displaystyle iL^{(2)} =i​L1(2)+i​Lk(2),absent𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿21𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝑘\displaystyle=iL^{(2)}_{1}+iL^{(2)}_{k}, (35)

where operators i​L1(i)𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑖1iL^{(i)}_{1} propagate the first mode and i​Lk(i)𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑖𝑘iL^{(i)}_{k} act only on the k>1𝑘1k>1 modes. They are

with

𝐅1​(𝐮)=𝐅1H-AdResS​(𝐮)−1P​[∑i=1P{ViQM​(𝐮)−ViCL​(𝐮)}]​∇𝐮1λ​(𝐮1)−[∑i=2P12​ξi​(m−M)​ωP2​𝐮i2]​∇𝐮1λ​(𝐮1)+∇𝒖1Δ​H​(𝒖1),subscript𝐅1𝐮subscriptsuperscript𝐅H-AdResS1𝐮1𝑃delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖QM𝐮superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖CL𝐮subscriptbold-∇subscript𝐮1𝜆subscript𝐮1delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑖2𝑃12subscript𝜉𝑖𝑚𝑀superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑃2superscriptsubscript𝐮𝑖2subscriptbold-∇subscript𝐮1𝜆subscript𝐮1subscriptbold-∇subscript𝒖1Δ𝐻subscript𝒖1\begin{split}\mathbf{F}_{1}(\mathbf{u})&=\mathbf{F}^{\textrm{H-AdResS}}_{1}(\mathbf{u})\\ &\qquad-\frac{1}{P}\left[\sum_{i=1}^{P}\left\{V_{i}^{\textrm{QM}}(\mathbf{u})-V_{i}^{\textrm{CL}}(\mathbf{u})\right\}\right]\bm{\nabla}_{\mathbf{u}_{1}}\lambda(\mathbf{u}_{1})\\ &\qquad-\left[\sum_{i=2}^{P}\frac{1}{2}\xi_{i}(m-M)\omega_{P}^{2}\mathbf{u}_{i}^{2}\right]\bm{\nabla}_{\mathbf{u}_{1}}\lambda(\mathbf{u}_{1})\\ &\qquad+\bm{\nabla}_{\bm{u}_{1}}\Delta H(\bm{u}_{1}),\end{split} (40)

The vector notation denotes that each Liouville operator in Eqs. 36-39 represents a set of three operators for each direction, which commute and can therefore be applied in arbitrary order.

In the first step we decompose the classical propagator exp⁡{i​L​t}𝑖𝐿𝑡\exp\{iLt\} as

ei​L​t=ei​L(1)​t+i​L(2)​t=limM→∞(ei​L(2)​t2​M​ei​L(1)​tM​ei​L(2)​t2​M)Msuperscript𝑒𝑖𝐿𝑡superscript𝑒𝑖superscript𝐿1𝑡𝑖superscript𝐿2𝑡subscript→𝑀superscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑖superscript𝐿2𝑡2𝑀superscript𝑒𝑖superscript𝐿1𝑡𝑀superscript𝑒𝑖superscript𝐿2𝑡2𝑀𝑀e^{iLt}=e^{iL^{(1)}t+iL^{(2)}t}=\lim_{M\rightarrow\infty}\left(e^{iL^{(2)}\frac{t}{2M}}e^{iL^{(1)}\frac{t}{M}}e^{iL^{(2)}\frac{t}{2M}}\right)^{M} (43)

using the symmetric Trotter theorem Trotter (1959); Strang (1968). Defining the time step Δ​t=t/MΔ𝑡𝑡𝑀\Delta t=t/M this yields the velocity Verlet integrator

ei​L​Δ​t≈ei​L(2)​Δ​t2​ei​L(1)​Δ​t​ei​L(2)​Δ​t2.superscript𝑒𝑖𝐿Δ𝑡superscript𝑒𝑖superscript𝐿2Δ𝑡2superscript𝑒𝑖superscript𝐿1Δ𝑡superscript𝑒𝑖superscript𝐿2Δ𝑡2e^{iL\Delta t}\approx e^{iL^{(2)}\frac{\Delta t}{2}}e^{iL^{(1)}\Delta t}e^{iL^{(2)}\frac{\Delta t}{2}}. (44)

However, recalling the definitions of i​L(1)𝑖superscript𝐿1iL^{(1)} and i​L(2)𝑖superscript𝐿2iL^{(2)} we recognize that their constituents i​L1(1)𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿11iL^{(1)}_{1} and i​Lk(1)𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿1𝑘iL^{(1)}_{k} as well as i​L1(2)𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿21iL^{(2)}_{1} and i​Lk(2)𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝑘iL^{(2)}_{k} do not commute. Therefore, using again the Trotter theorem, we decompose each of the propagators in Eq. 44 further to

ei​L​Δ​t≈ei​L(2)​Δ​t2​ei​L(1)​Δ​t​ei​L(2)​Δ​t2≈(ei​Lk(2)​Δ​t4​ei​L1(2)​Δ​t2​ei​Lk(2)​Δ​t4)​(ei​L1(1)​Δ​t2​ei​Lk(1)​Δ​t​ei​L1(1)​Δ​t2)​(ei​Lk(2)​Δ​t4​ei​L1(2)​Δ​t2​ei​Lk(2)​Δ​t4),superscript𝑒𝑖𝐿Δ𝑡superscript𝑒𝑖superscript𝐿2Δ𝑡2superscript𝑒𝑖superscript𝐿1Δ𝑡superscript𝑒𝑖superscript𝐿2Δ𝑡2superscript𝑒𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝑘Δ𝑡4superscript𝑒𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿21Δ𝑡2superscript𝑒𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝑘Δ𝑡4superscript𝑒𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿11Δ𝑡2superscript𝑒𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿1𝑘Δ𝑡superscript𝑒𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿11Δ𝑡2superscript𝑒𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝑘Δ𝑡4superscript𝑒𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿21Δ𝑡2superscript𝑒𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝑘Δ𝑡4\begin{split}e^{iL\Delta t}&\approx e^{iL^{(2)}\frac{\Delta t}{2}}e^{iL^{(1)}\Delta t}e^{iL^{(2)}\frac{\Delta t}{2}}\\ &\approx\left(e^{iL^{(2)}_{k}\frac{\Delta t}{4}}e^{iL^{(2)}_{1}\frac{\Delta t}{2}}e^{iL^{(2)}_{k}\frac{\Delta t}{4}}\right)\left(e^{iL^{(1)}_{1}\frac{\Delta t}{2}}e^{iL^{(1)}_{k}\Delta t}e^{iL^{(1)}_{1}\frac{\Delta t}{2}}\right)\left(e^{iL^{(2)}_{k}\frac{\Delta t}{4}}e^{iL^{(2)}_{1}\frac{\Delta t}{2}}e^{iL^{(2)}_{k}\frac{\Delta t}{4}}\right),\end{split} (45)

which is correct up to second order in Δ​tΔ𝑡\Delta t and is suited for the integration of the system’s equations of motion. Note that for the CKM approach, the adaptive mass νk′​(𝐮1)subscriptsuperscript𝜈′𝑘subscript𝐮1\nu^{\prime}_{k}(\mathbf{u}_{1}) in i​Lk(1)𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿1𝑘iL^{(1)}_{k}, Eq. 37, would be constant and also the 𝐩k2superscriptsubscript𝐩𝑘2\mathbf{p}_{k}^{2} term in i​L1(2)𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿21iL^{(2)}_{1}, Eq. 38, would be missing. Therefore, no second decomposition level would be required and we could stick with velocity Verlet.

The interpretation of the integration scheme in Eq. 45 is straightforward. The first and the last term in brackets (⋯)⋯(\cdots) correspond to the propagation of momenta, while the term in the middle propagates coordinates. The next decomposition level tells us how to update the momenta and the coordinates. The momenta are integrated in the following way: We first propagate all higher mode momenta by a quarter step, then we update the 𝐩k2superscriptsubscript𝐩𝑘2\mathbf{p}_{k}^{2} term in i​L1(2)𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐿12iL_{1}^{(2)} using these new momenta and propagate the first mode’s momentum by a half step. Next, we perform the other quarter step for the higher modes. To get the full time step, the procedure is repeated after the position update in the center of the scheme. The coordinates are updated as follows: We first propagate the first mode by a half step using i​L1(1)𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐿11iL_{1}^{(1)}. Then we update the adaptive masses in the Liouville operator i​Lk(1)𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐿𝑘1iL_{k}^{(1)} and propagate the higher modes by a full step. Finally, we integrate the first mode by another half step. The scheme requires little additional computational overhead compared to a regular velocity Verlet scheme. The number of additional operations scales only linearly with the number of particles, and the force computation, usually the numerically most demanding part of a simulation, has to be performed as usual only once after all coordinates are fully propagated.

Finally, we want to address the symplecticity of the new integrator. The Hamiltonian HPakmsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑃akmH_{P}^{\textrm{akm}}, Eq. 25, is not trivially separable into two parts, one depending only on coordinates and one containing only momenta. However, it has no term in which both the momentum and the corresponding conjugate coordinate of the same mode appear together. This is a result of our choice of the adaptive masses: The higher mode masses are position dependent, but they do not depend on their own mode coordinates but only on the centroid coordinate. However, the centroid itself, which determines the resolution and the masses of the ring polymers, is associated with a constant mass. Therefore, the Hamiltonian HPakmsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑃akmH_{P}^{\textrm{akm}} and the corresponding equations of motion still define a symplectic structure. As a consequence, also the integration scheme in Eq. 45 is symplectic, as it is constructed in a rigorous fashion from HPakmsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑃akmH_{P}^{\textrm{akm}}’s equations of motion using the Liouville operator formalism. This can also be understood considering the Liouville operators themselves: The operator i​Lk(1)𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿1𝑘iL^{(1)}_{k}, Eq. 37, which propagates the higher mode coordinates 𝐮ksubscript𝐮𝑘\mathbf{u}_{k} does have an additional position dependence but only on the centroid mode. Hence, it can be applied as usual in a well-defined manner. Similarly, the operator i​L1(2)𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿21iL^{(2)}_{1}, Eq. 38, propagating the momentum of the centroid mode has an additional dependence on momenta, but only on the higher mode momenta. Consequently, the determinant J𝐽J of the time evolution matrix is 111. The symplecticity has the practical advantage that we are able to derive an energy conserving integrator, which, in our case, is exact up to second order in time, similar to a regular velocity Verlet.

It is worth pointing out that the previous observation is in contrast with earlier works using adaptive masses Rudnicki, Lesyng, and Harvey (1994); Potestio (2014). There, both momenta and the corresponding conjugate coordinates appear together in the same terms in the Hamiltonian. Hence, in those cases, Liouville’s theorem no longer holds, the Liouville operator formalism breaks down, and symplecticity is lost.

III.6 Multiple time-stepping

In typical complex soft matter systems, non-bonded interactions as well as bonds, angles and dihedrals generate motion on different time scales. In PIMD, we have additionally the springs between the beads of the ring polymers onto which the quantum particles are mapped. If the kinetic masses for the higher modes are small, they vibrate strongly, which requires a small integration time step. When only sampling statistical averages, the kinetic masses can be chosen freely, for example, such that all higher modes vibrate with the same frequency. When calculating approximate quantum dynamical quantities, however, the kinetic mode masses must either correspond to the real ones, as in RPMD, or must be significantly decreased, as in CMD. This leads to an internal ring polymer dynamics which is significantly faster than the motion due to typical interatomic non-bonded or bonded potentials. Furthermore, in the CKM approach, the modes’ oscillation frequencies are increased in the CL region, as the kinetic mass will be small there compared to the increased spring mass. This strongly motivates the introduction of multiple time-stepping into our integrator.

We employ the RESPA scheme Tuckerman, Berne, and Martyna (1992) and decompose the force computation into three parts: one for non-bonded forces, a second for the bonds, and a third for the internal ring polymer motion. The first drift term, 𝐅1driftsuperscriptsubscript𝐅1drift\mathbf{F}_{1}^{\textrm{drift}}, depends only on the energies associated with the non-bonded potentials and is therefore evaluated together with the rest of the non-bonded forces. The second and the third drift terms 𝐅2driftsuperscriptsubscript𝐅2drift\mathbf{F}_{2}^{\textrm{drift}} and 𝐅3driftsuperscriptsubscript𝐅3drift\mathbf{F}_{3}^{\textrm{drift}}, however, depend directly on the motion of the higher modes and therefore need to be evaluated together with them. Hence, we define

i​Lk(1)𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿1𝑘\displaystyle iL^{(1)}_{k} =\displaystyle= 𝐩kν~​(𝐮1)​∂∂𝐮k,subscript𝐩𝑘~𝜈subscript𝐮1subscript𝐮𝑘\displaystyle\frac{\mathbf{p}_{k}}{\tilde{\nu}(\mathbf{u}_{1})}\frac{\partial}{\partial\mathbf{u}_{k}}, (47)
